recent.Timeless: Maintains high popularity (top 100) consistently across all 30 years with minimal variation in rank (Â±20 positions)
recent.Steady Classic: Remains in top 200 throughout the period with moderate fluctuations, never dropping below the top 300
recent.Comeback: Dropped significantly (fell out of top 500) for at least 10 years mid-period, then returned to top 200 in recent years
recent.Shooting Star: Dramatic rise of 300+ positions over the past 5-7 years, currently in top 200
recent.Slow Burn: Gradual, consistent upward trajectory over 20+ years, gaining at least 200 positions total
recent.Fading Glory: Was top 100 for at least 10 years, now ranked 500+ or unranked
recent.Flash Trend: Sudden spike to popularity (top 100) for 3-5 years, then declined rapidly
recent.Cultural Moment: Sharp popularity spike correlating with specific cultural events (celebrity naming, media), followed by decline
recent.Generational: Peaked in a specific decade, clearly associated with one generation (e.g., popular years 1-10, rare afterwards)
recent.Sleeper: Remained in the 200-500 range consistently for 25+ years, never breaking through to top tier
recent.Volatile: Experiences multiple significant swings (150+ position changes) throughout the period with no clear pattern
recent.New Entrant: First appeared in rankings within past 10 years, currently gaining momentum
recent.Vintage Revival: Was unranked or very rare for 15+ years, recently re-entered top 500
recent.Declining Classic: Started in top 50, experiencing steady decline but still ranked in top 300
recent.Uncategorized: Does not fit clearly into any defined classification pattern

historic.Century Classic: Appears in top 100 in 10+ decades across the entire period, never absent for more than one consecutive decade
historic.Golden Age: Dominated (top 20) for 3-5 consecutive decades, then faded from top 100
historic.Early Century: Top 100 from 1910s-1950s, largely disappeared by 1970s onwards
historic.Mid-Century: Peak popularity 1940s-1970s, minimal presence before or after
historic.Late Century: Emerged in top 100 during 1970s-1990s, maintaining or growing since
historic.Modern Era: First entered top 100 in 2000s or later
historic.Pendulum: Was popular in early decades (1910s-1930s), disappeared mid-century, returned to top 100 in recent decades (2000s+)
historic.Lost Generation: Top 100 in early decades (pre-1950s), hasn't returned to top 100 since
historic.Steady Decline: Started in top 100 in 1910s, gradually declining each decade, may or may not still rank
historic.Steady Rise: Started outside or barely in top 100 in early decades, consistently climbing, now firmly established
historic.Peak and Fade: Reached top 10 in at least one decade, then dropped out of top 100 entirely within 3-4 decades
historic.Brief Moment: Appeared in top 100 for only 1-3 non-consecutive decades across the entire period
historic.Resilient: Consistently appears in top 100 across 7-9 decades but never reaches top 20
historic.Intermittent: Appears in top 100 for 4-6 decades but with significant gaps (missing 2+ consecutive decades)
historic.Revolutionary: Sharp entry into top 100 coinciding with major cultural shifts (1960s counterculture, 1990s tech era, etc.)
historic.Uncategorized: Does not fit clearly into any defined classification pattern
